Arbitrage Bot Glossary — Card Preview

Compact tutorial cards for key terms used by the trustless arbitrage smart contract.

Preview only — UI actions are mockups
Flash loan
Uncollateralized loan repaid within one transaction
Core

Borrow funds (e.g., via Aave) to fund an arbitrage, perform swaps, and repay the loan plus premium within the same transaction to keep net profit.

Learn more ↗
Two‑leg arbitrage
Capture spreads using two swaps across DEXes
Core

Swap A→B on DEX 1, then B→A on DEX 2 (e.g., WETH↔USDC) to pocket the price difference after fees.

Learn more ↗
DEX (Uniswap V2/V3, Sushiswap, Balancer)
On‑chain AMMs and liquidity pools
Core

Choose the DEX with the best price/gas profile; V3 offers concentrated liquidity while Balancer supports multi-token pools and custom weights.

Uniswap V3 ↗
WETH / ETH wrapping
ERC‑20 wrapper for native ETH
Utility

Wrap ETH to WETH so it can be used in ERC‑20 swap paths and approved by routers or contracts; unwrap to send native ETH as profit.

Learn more ↗
Route profit estimation
Predict expected output & net profit
Estimation

Use on‑chain calls for V2-like routers and approximations for V3/Balancer to estimate outputs, fees, slippage, and net profit for candidate routes.

Learn more ↗
Gas estimation (per-route)
Estimate gas units & ETH cost
Estimation

Estimate gas per DEX route—Uniswap V3 and Balancer often cost more gas; include gas in profit calculations to avoid loss-making routes.

Learn more ↗
Slippage (max slippage)
Allowed % deviation in execution price
Safety

Reject routes exceeding MAX_SLIPPAGE (e.g., 10%) to avoid executing trades that deviate too far from expected prices.

Learn more ↗
Trade size limit (MAX_TRADE_AMOUNT)
Immutable cap on attempted trade amount
Safety

Limit trade size (e.g., 100 ETH) to prevent market-moving swaps that could destroy profitability.

Learn more ↗
Minimum profit threshold
Minimum net profit to execute
Economics

Require net profit above a threshold (e.g., 0.001 ETH) after gas and fees before launching a flash loan-backed arbitrage.

Learn more ↗
Per‑user rate limiting
Cooldowns and daily caps per user
Safety

Enforce cooldown periods and daily caps to prevent abuse and reduce systemic risk from one user monopolizing opportunities.

Learn more ↗
Aave flash loan callback
executeOperation where you run logic & repay
Core

Execute arbitrage in the callback and ensure the borrowed principal + premium is repaid before the callback ends to avoid revert.

Learn more ↗
ERC‑20 approvals & allowances
approve / transferFrom permission model
Utility

Grant allowances so routers or the arbitrage contract can pull tokens for swaps and loan repayments.

Learn more ↗
Repayment + premium
Flash loan must be returned with protocol fee
Economics

Ensure arbitrage covers the borrowed amount plus premium; otherwise the whole transaction will revert and yield no profit.

Learn more ↗
Event emission & on‑chain stats
Logs for UI & analytics
Observability

Emit OpportunityFound and ArbitrageExecuted events so front‑ends can index and display opportunities and results to users.

Learn more ↗
Token / pool whitelisting
Restrict to approved tokens & pools
Safety

Limit contract interactions to preapproved tokens (WETH, USDC, USDT, DAI, WBTC) and validated Balancer pool IDs to reduce risk.

Learn more ↗
Uniswap V3 exact‑input single‑hop
Exact input swap in a single V3 pool
DEX

Use single‑hop exact‑input when trading a known input amount across one concentrated‑liquidity pool for predictable output estimates.

Learn more ↗
Balancer single swap / Vault
Vault-mediated swaps in Balancer pools
DEX

Execute single-token-for-token swaps through the Balancer Vault when pool weights and fees make it favorable.

Learn more ↗
Immutable safety constants
Immutable limits set at deployment
Safety

Use immutable variables (MAX_SLIPPAGE, MAX_TRADE_AMOUNT) to enforce security constraints that cannot be altered at runtime.

Learn more ↗
WETH withdrawal (unwrap)
Convert WETH back to native ETH
Utility

After arbitrage, unwrap WETH to ETH and transfer native ETH to the initiating user as profit if desired.

Learn more ↗
Opportunity scanning
Sample multiple trade sizes to find best route
Search

Probe trade sizes (10%, 25%, 50%) across routes using StartNative to find the best OpportunityData while limiting price impact.

Learn more ↗
MEV considerations
Front‑running, sandwiching, and extraction risks
Risk

Protect transactions from mempool exposure (private relays, bundles) to reduce front‑running and sandwich attacks that reduce arbitrage profit.

Learn more ↗
Reentrancy & repay‑safety checks
Guards and checks to prevent exploits
Security

Use reentrancy guards and checks-effects-interactions patterns and verify repayment amounts before transferring profits to avoid vulnerabilities.
